statement:
The characteristic polynomial of a orthogonal matrix is a reciprocal
polynomial

Let $A$ be the orthogonal matrix, and let
$p(\lambda) = \det(A-\lambda I)$ be its characteristic polynomial. We
wish to prove that $$p(\lambda) = \pm \lambda^n p(1/\lambda).$$ Since
$A^{-1}=A^T$, we have $A-\lambda I=-\lambda A (A^T-I/\lambda ).$ Taking
the determinant of both sides, and using $\det A = \det A^T$ and
$\det c A = c^n \det A$ ($c\in \mathbb{C}$), yields
$$\det (A-\lambda I) = \pm \lambda^n \det(A-\frac{1}{\lambda} I).$$

[9]{} H. Eves, *Elementary Matrix Theory*, Dover publications, 1980.
names: characteristic polynomial of a orthogonal matrix is a reciprocal polynomial
